net.nologin.meep.tbv

Interface TileProvider

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    GenericTileProvider

    public interface TileProvider
    Provider of Tile data for the TiledBitmapView (TBV from here on).

    Provider Overview:

    The TBV is a scrollable SurfaceView which requires a TileProvider to deliver the contained selection of bitmap data as the user manipulates the view. The data is referenced as a conceptual 2D plane of square tiles, with (x,y) coordinates as IDs (eg, (0,0)(0,1)(0,2) for three horizontally sequential tiles). As the user manipulates the TBV, it informs the provider of the current 'visible' range of tile IDs, and fetches the respective Tile objects from the provider as it renders the surface.

    Lifecycle Summary:
    • There are several getConfig*() methods that are used to setup the TBV.
    • Based on screen state (ie screen dimensions, zoom level, scroll offset), the TBV calculates what range of Tile IDs are required to render the surface, and informs the provider via onTileIDRangeChange(TileRange). This will be called any time that a TBV manipulation results in a change in the range of required IDs (eg, user scrolls, screen rotation).
    • When refreshing the surface, the TBV's rendering thread will call getTile(int, int) for each Tile in that range. Tiles without bitmap data at this time are rendered as empty squares. This allows for implementations where the tiles gradually appear as the provider makes the bitmaps available.


    Performance
    Simple (ie 'fast') solutions can just ignore the onTileIDRangeChange(TileRange) calls and populate the bitmap data on the fly for each getTile(int, int) call. This approach can have several issues:
    1. Heap Space: Depending on the app, the user may scroll around the same area repeatedly. It can improve performance to maintain a bitmap cache in your provider, rather than generate/fetch each time. However, as the user scrolls around, this can exhaust heap memory. (Turning on TiledBitmapView.setDebugEnabled(boolean) can help you see any jumps in heap use as you scroll). Use onTileIDRangeChange(TileRange) to see which tiles in your cache are well out of view, and remove them.
    2. Responsiveness: No calls to any of the interface methods should result in long-running or blocking activity. At best, tiles will be slow to appear, at worst the app will become unresponsive or cause an ANR. Instead, when onTileIDRangeChange(TileRange) is called, trigger a background task to process the queue of any tiles that need populating. In the meantime, calls to getTile(int, int) for unprocessed tiles should tiles with null bitmap data. The TBV constantly polls the hasFreshData() method, and should it return true, the TBV will trigger a fresh surface render, and therefore a fresh set of calls to getTile(int, int). The onSurfaceDestroyed() method can be used to stop any outstanding background tasks when the view is closed.
    3. User Complaints: Maybe your solution isn't fast, it just seems it on your quad core 2ghz plaything.


    Background Rendering & Threads

    The TiledBitmapView is a SurfaceView subclass that uses a separate thread to render the actual contents of the surface. Most methods - those related to setup, and view/range change notification are invoked on the main UI thread as the user interacts with the TBV. However, since the surface is rendered by a seperate thread, methods such as getTile(int, int) and hasFreshData() will be invoked on that seperate thread.

    It is up to the implementation to ensure that variables accessed by the two threads are handled in a safe manner. Methods are documented to confirm whether they are invoked by the UI or the rendering thread.

    See Also:
    GenericTileProvider: A simple implementation (that can also be extended).

    • Method Detail

      • getConfigTileSize

        int getConfigTileSize()
        Get the side length (in px) of the square Tile objects generated by this provider.

        Thread: Main UI - See class javadoc
        Returns:
        The side length (in pixels) of the square tiles generated by this provider.

      • getConfigTileIDLimits

        java.lang.Integer[] getConfigTileIDLimits()
        If specified, scrolling past these tile ID limits in the view will be prohibited.
        Useful to prevent scrolling past excessive ranges, or also in conjuction with getConfigGridAnchor() when your data has a logical boundary. Unspecified behaviour occurs if the bounds are too restrictive (ie, less than the initial range displayed on the screen).

        Thread: Main UI - See class javadoc
        Returns:
        null if there are no restrictions on scrolling. Otherwise, a 4-element Integer array should be specified, specifying the left, top, right, and bottom ID limits respectively. Each individual element can be null to selectively allow unlimited scrolling. Eg, to enforce that scrolling up can't go beyond x=5, then specify {null,null,5,null}. Invalid arrays will be ignored (same as null).

      • getConfigGridAnchor

        GridAnchor getConfigGridAnchor()
        When one of the moveTo* methods in TiledBitmapView is called, the desired Tile will be moved into view. This GridAnchor value defines where exactly on the screen that Tile will end up. In map-style views (or if unsure), generally GridAnchor.Center is sufficent.

        Thread: Main UI - See class javadoc
        Returns:
        The relative position on the screen that target tiles will be rendered.

      • getTile

        Tile getTile(int x,
           int y)
        Get the specified tile.

        Thread: Surface Renderer (Not UI) - See class javadoc
        Parameters:
        x - The tile's x-coordinate
        y - The tile's y-coordinate
        Returns:
        The tile. Don't return null: If the bitmap isn't ready, return a tile without the bitmap data set.

      • hasFreshData

        boolean hasFreshData()
        Useful when this provider performs background queue processing, this method is polled by the view to check if there are fresh bitmaps to include in the next rendering of the surface. The implementation of this method should probably toggle the flag back to false in order to prevent unecessary repeat renderings.

        Thread: Surface Renderer (Not UI) - See class javadoc
        Returns:
        true if this provider has generated new bitmap data that should be included since the last call.

      • onTileIDRangeChange

        void onTileIDRangeChange(TileRange newRange)
        Called by the view when it calculates a change in the visble tile range. This gives the provider a chance to clear out older cached data, or to trigger background tasks to generate/fetch new tile bitmap data. Return true from hasFreshData() to let the view know when any background task has produced new data it can use.

        Thread: Main UI - See class javadoc
        Parameters:
        newRange - The boundaries of the tile IDs fpsTimeNow on display.

      • onZoomFactorChange

        void onZoomFactorChange(float newZoom)
        Called by the view when the user uses pinch-zoom

        Thread: Main UI - See class javadoc
        Parameters:
        newZoom - a float value from 1.0 to 5.0 (initial is 1.0)

      • onSurfaceDestroyed

        void onSurfaceDestroyed()
        Called when the view's surface is being destroyed, giving the provider a chance to shutdown any background tasks.

        Thread: Main UI - See class javadoc

      • getDebugSummary

        java.lang.String getDebugSummary()
        Generate a short summary string with the state of this provider. When TiledBitmapView.setDebugEnabled(boolean) has been set true, this string will be displayed as part of the debug information at the bottom right. Although only called during debug mode, depending on your provider, it may be called a lot, so keep it as resource efficient as possible.

        Thread: Surface Renderer (Not UI) - See class javadoc
        Returns:
        Short descriptive summary of this provider's state, eg "MyProv[cache=100,blah=123]".
